title: Pacman Frog Enclosure Setup: Size Requirements, Types & Decorations
description: Complete guide to Pacman frog enclosure requirements including size by sex, enclosure types (glass/PVC/screen), bin modifications, decorations, and enrichment setup.
author: Habitat Builder
excerpt: Learn proper enclosure sizing for male and female Pacman frogs, enclosure type selection, bin modifications, and enrichment setup for thriving frogs.

content.heading: Proper Housing for Thriving Pacman Frogs
content.text: Pacman frogs can get rather large - females up to 7 inches diameter! Though they can be inactive day-to-day, they explore and move at night when provided enriching spaces. Larger, well-decorated enclosures encourage natural activity patterns and burrowing behavior. These frogs are cannibalistic and MUST be housed alone.
SOLITARY SPECIES ONLY - Pacman frogs are cannibalistic. Never house two frogs together under any circumstances, regardless of size or sex.
A 10 gallon tank is NOT appropriate housing for adult frogs of either sex. Here's why:

items: Unable to establish proper thermal gradient (warm to cool side)
Insufficient floor space for exploration and burrow changes
No room for enrichment (multiple hides, plants, decorations)
Females can grow to 7 inches - physically cramped in 10 gallon
Stress from inadequate space suppresses immune system

content.text: When provided with larger enclosures and better decoration, Pacman frogs are more likely to explore and change burrows at night. Enriching spaces promote natural behaviors.
Pacman frogs differ greatly in size between males and females, so minimum enclosure sizes differ. Make sure you properly sex your frog before committing to the smaller male minimum.
Minimum Height: All enclosures require minimum 12 inches of height, but 18+ inches makes heating and lighting much easier to manage.
Minimum Size: 20×10×12" (50×25×30cm) or 200 sq in floor space

Breeders and pet stores sell frogs as young as quarter-sized. Baby frogs at this age have not been tested for growth, food response, and health. Smaller enclosures help monitor health during this vulnerable time. Upgrade to adult enclosure once 6-7 months old and able to be sexed.
Example Enclosures:

items: Modified plastic bins of appropriate size (check interior dimensions)

content.text: UPGRADE REQUIRED - Juveniles must be moved to adult-sized enclosure at 6-7 months old. Keeping adult frogs in 10 gallon tanks causes chronic stress and health issues.
Minimum Size: 30×12×12" (75×30×30cm) or 360 sq in floor space (20 gallon long equivalent)
Males grow to 3-4 inches diameter. Larger enclosures are always welcome and encouraged!
Example Enclosures:

items: Modified plastic bins of appropriate size (check interior dimensions)

content.text: Minimum Size: 36×18×18" (90×45×45cm) or 648 sq in floor space (40 gallon breeder equivalent)
Females grow to 5-7 inches diameter depending on species. They need significantly more space than males.
Example Enclosures:

items: Zilla QuickBuild Terrarium (48×18×18") - extra large option
Modified plastic bins of appropriate size (check interior dimensions)

Best for: High humidity species (C. cornuta, C. aurita), budget-conscious keepers, those wanting easy viewing

Cons:

content.text: Tips: Cover 50-75% of screen top with HVAC tape, foil, or acrylic to retain humidity on cool side. Keep warm side open for heat lamp.
Best for: Serious keepers, multiple frogs in different enclosures, those wanting front-opening access
Pros:

items: Can have integrated drainage for bioactive

content.text: Screen enclosures are generally NOT recommended for Pacman frogs unless you live in a naturally humid environment (Florida, Hawaii, etc.) or have automated misting systems.
Plastic storage bins can be used for quarantine, grow-out enclosures, or transportation. They are NOT suitable as permanent housing for adult frogs.
When to use bins:
Required modifications:

items: Cut out center of lid (leave 2-3 inch border)
Replace cutout with 1/4 inch or smaller hardware cloth mesh
Secure mesh with zip ties, screws, or strong adhesive
Mesh allows ventilation and safe overhead heat use
Smooth any sharp edges that could injure frog

content.text: CRITICAL: UVB cannot be used with plastic bin enclosures. UVB radiation reacts with plastic to create toxic chemicals and makes plastic brittle. Bins are UVB-incompatible even with mesh lid.
For bin modification questions, contact experienced keepers on r/pacmanfrogs subreddit.
Pacman frogs need coverage and decorations for security and enrichment. Many frogs burrow under plants, wood pieces, and leaf litter rather than sitting exposed.
While frogs burrow to hide, they still benefit from overhead coverage. Provide options on both warm and cool sides of enclosure.
Hide options:

items: Cork bark slabs and rounds (natural, holds humidity)
Commercial hides WITHOUT bottoms (must allow burrowing)
Half log hides depressed into substrate
Terra cotta pots (break off rim, bury edge)
Live or fake plants with broad leaves

content.text: Avoid hides with plastic bottoms - frogs cannot burrow under them, preventing natural behavior. Remove bottoms or use natural hides that rest on substrate.
Leaf litter should be added on top of substrate. Benefits:

items: Frogs burrow under large leaf pieces
Provides habitat for cleanup crew in bioactive setups

content.text: Best leaf types: Magnolia (large, durable), oak leaves, catappa/Indian almond leaves, commercial reptile leaf litter
Live plants (best for bioactive):
Artificial plants:
Breaking up overhead lighting is especially beneficial for albino frogs but enriching for all morphs:

items: Allows frog to choose sun/shade preference
Branches and sticks (not for climbing, but enrichment)
Cork rounds (create tunnels when partially buried)
Stones and rocks (smooth edges only, not small enough to swallow)
Background images (taped to outside of enclosure)

content.text: Some frogs use water dishes extensively, others rarely. Fresh clean water should be provided at all times regardless.
Water dish requirements:

items: Frog must fit entire body in dish for soaking
Water depth: Frog sits with body under water but NOT fully submerged
Pacman frogs are poor swimmers (short legs, small feet, no webbing)
Frog must be able to exit dish without assistance
Smooth sides with gradual slope or steps

content.text: Dish placement:

items: Place on cool side of enclosure (prevents rapid evaporation)
Bury rim level with substrate (easy access)
Keep away from heat lamp (maintains cooler water)

content.text: Water maintenance:

items: Change water daily (frogs often defecate in dish)
ALL water must be treated with reptile/amphibian dechlorinator
Clean dish weekly with reptile-safe cleaner

content.text: Water dish too deep = drowning risk. Pacman frogs are NOT strong swimmers and can drown in deep water. They should always be able to touch bottom and keep head above water.
Thermal gradient setup:

items: Heat lamp and UVB on one side (warm side)
Keep opposite side empty of heat sources (cool side)
Place warm-side hide under heat lamp
Place cool-side hide away from heat

content.text: Avoid these layout mistakes:

items: Heat sources on both sides (no thermal gradient)
Water dish directly under heat lamp (rapid evaporation)
All hides clustered in one area (no temperature choice)
Decorations too close to heat lamp (fire hazard)

content.text: Before adding your frog:

items: ✓ Enclosure minimum size met (20 gal males, 40 gal females)
✓ Leaf litter on top of substrate
✓ Heat lamp on one side (see heating & lighting guide)
✓ Thermometer probes on warm and cool sides
✓ Hygrometer probes on warm and cool sides
✓ Water dish on cool side (treated water)
✓ Let enclosure stabilize 24-48 hours before adding frog

rows: Change water dish, spot clean visible waste, check temperatures/humidity
Mist substrate if needed, clean water dish, check all equipment functioning
Replace leaf litter as it decomposes
Deep clean decorations, check substrate moisture throughout depth
Replace substrate (except bioactive), full enclosure cleaning

content.text: For those pursuing bioactive setups, add these components:

items: Drainage layer (1-2 inches LECA or hydroballs with screen barrier)
Bioactive substrate mix (ABG Mix or Terra Firma)
Cleanup crew (dwarf white or powder orange isopods + temperate springtails)
Increased leaf litter (food source for CUC)
Reduced maintenance (no substrate changes, minimal spot cleaning)
Buy used aquariums (check Craigslist, Facebook Marketplace, local reptile groups)
Use organic topsoil instead of pet store substrate ($2-5 vs $8-15)
Collect natural decor (branches, stones) - bake at 200°F for 30 min to sterilize
Use terra cotta pots as hides (break off rim, $1-3 each)
Buy feeder insects in bulk online (much cheaper than pet stores)
DIY background with foam and silicone
Join local reptile groups for free/cheap supplies
Enclosure too small for sex (10 gallon for adults)
No thermal gradient (heat sources everywhere or nowhere)
Insufficient substrate depth (frog visible when burrowed)
Using bin enclosures with UVB (toxic reaction)
No cool side hide (can't escape heat)
